awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Framework For Economical Cyber Security Inspection and Assurance
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to develop and apply smart inspection methods to keep the costs of cyber security low, while ensuring the security of scientific results. Many other industries use statistical sampling and sequential inspection methods for quality assurance. Yet, at present much of cyber security relies on attempted inspection of either 100% of items of a given type (such as top priority domain name server logs) or 0% (such as many types of possible hardware inspections). Working across two major universities, Ohio State University and the University of Wisconsin, the project develops new inspection methods, tailored to cyber security objectives. Specific objectives relate to hardware, cyber software vulnerabilities, log inspection, and emergency management and related scientific research. The project explores the usefulness of these new methods to senior quality professionals to support widespread adoption. By working smarter and not harder, scientists using this approach can feel more confident that their results are trustworthy, and, at the same time, the cost curve can be bent so that research can remain cost-competitive.

Specifically, the project models security metrics probabilistically and develops patterns of testing to estimate these metrics. The research addresses a variety of domains and cyber security challenges: (1) supercomputing log and hardware inspections, (2) ordinary department vulnerability sampling and estimation and improved logging and sampling (focusing on scientific infrastructure), (3) highly resourced department stratified sampling hardware, improved vulnerability decision-making, and strategic log generation and sampling, and (4) the UW Emergency Management system center. Metrics from attack-defend and standard quality assurance will be explored and serve as validation outputs for the techniques. This project seeks to meet the vital security needs by formulating an assurance framework that adapts and extends existing methods in quality control and assurance to the cyber domain. The assurance framework offers many advantages: it can address sequential decision-making, it can seek solutions that are robust to uncertain data, and it balances cost with threat reduction. The inspection methods to be studied include Multiple Complete Inspection & Inspector Inspection, Attempted 100% Inspection with Optimal Supplementation, Stratified Sampling, Sequential Sampling, and Optimal Multi-Fidelity Inspection. In each case, operating characteristic curves and other estimates of system integrity will be developed and applied. A key and unique element of the proposed approach is the combination of multiple inspection methods, including new methods, to provide a comprehensive framework for cost-effectively enhancing integrity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overall, we demonstrated that optimal inspection has a great likelihood of majorly reducing cybersecurity costs and incidents. We divide outcomes into three groups: (1) outcomes directly related to innovative inspection methods in cybersecurity, (2) clarification of information needs by studying cybersecurity decision problems, and (3) other research inspired by the investigations.

(1) Directly related to cybersecurity inspection goals, we studied the problem of optimal inspection and demonstrated, based on real data from a Midwest university, that significant savings (over half of incident and maintenance costs) could be eliminated with improved inspection and other policies (Liu, Allen, and Roychowdhury (2019). To clarify the issues of inspection further in cybersecurity, a nested birth and death simulation model was developed (Murali, Liu, and Allen 2019). These results establish the critical role of optimal inspection in vulnerability management achieving a primary objective of the project.

In Allen et al. 2021, we discuss what data might be needed to optimal design industrial control system (ICS) internal firewalls and inspection protocols. We propose a preliminary “Ohio State Model of ICS Cybersecurity” responding to the well-known “Purdue Model” which many believe needs an update. The tentative proposal is that vulnerability scans and penetration tests should regularly be applied, and adjustments made to directional allowances (if any) among ICS elements such as building control systems and manufacturing machines.

(2) Understanding the decision problems relating to cybersecurity is critical to clarifying what inspection is needed. In Enayaty-Ahangar et al. (2021), we survey many decision problems in cybersecurity. Problems studied include packet inspection and deep packet inspection. Conclusions are provided about which industries need more applications of the related decision-models including communications and transportation. The implications of enhanced attack graphs on decision-making with implications for inspection planning are clarified in Schmidt, Albert, and Zheng (2021) and Wang and Albert (2022). Attack graphs imply, in general, that not all vulnerabilities are important to inspect. If hosts and vulnerabilities do not play possible roles in relevant graphs, expenses can conceivably be saved.

(3) The participants supported by this project also participated in research of possible relevance to the subject of cybersecurity inspection. In Allen, Hernandez, and Alomair (2020), we clarified how data can be obtained efficiently (inspected) from experiments to clarify what the equilibria are in the game theory representations of cybersecurity situations. This was probably the first study of experimental design to support practical game theory. Similarly, in Allen, Yang, Huang, and Hernandez (2020), we clarified the optimal approach to provision resources in elections to equalize waiting lines. These lines could, conceivably, be influenced by cyber-attacks. We also describe case study implementations involving the authors and the rigorous guarantees offered which could support success in legal courts.
